name: Unemployment rate
description: The percentage of the labor force that is unemployed and actively seeking employment. It is calculated as the number of unemployed persons divided by the total labor force. A measure that expresses the frequency of occurrence of an event or phenomenon in relation to another quantity.

name: Coal, South Africa, Export price, US dollars per metric tonne
description: Coal, South African export price, US$ per metric ton. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to preserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published. The export price of a commodity. Price or cost in US dollars per metric tonne.

name: External debt: total debt service, amortization, US dollar
description: Total external debt amortization charges reflect the amortization (interest and regular payments) charges related to gross external debt during the accounting period.  Gross external debt reflects liabilities that require payment(s) of interest and/or principal by the debtor at some point(s) in the future and that are owed to non-residents by residents of an economy.

name: External debt: total debt service, interest, US dollar
description: Total external debt interest charges reflect the interest payments related to gross external debt during the accounting period.  Gross external debt reflects liabilities that require payment(s) of interest and/or principal by the debtor at some point(s) in the future and that are owed to non-residents by residents of an economy.

name: External debt: total debt service, amortization, Percent of GDP
description: Total external debt amortization charges reflect the amortization (interest and regular payments) charges related to gross external debt during the accounting period.  Gross external debt reflects liabilities that require payment(s) of interest and/or principal by the debtor at some point(s) in the future and that are owed to non-residents by residents of an economy. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Exports of goods and services, US dollar
description: The export (sale or barter) of physical, produced objects (goods) and services over which ownership rights can be established and whose ownership can be transferred from one institutional unit to another by engaging in transactions on markets by residents in one territory to residents in another territory. Exports reflect a change in the economic ownership of goods from residents of the compiling economy to non-residents, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to perserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published.

name: Imports of goods and services, US dollar
description: Total current and capital account balances (credit less debit)

name: External debt: total debt service, US dollar
description: Total external debt service charges reflect the amortization (interest and regular payments) and principle payments related to gross external debt during the accounting period.  Gross external debt reflects liabilities that require payment(s) of interest and/or principal by the debtor at some point(s) in the future and that are owed to non-residents by residents of an economy.

name: Terms of trade of goods and services, percent change
description: The percentage change in the terms of trade of goods and services over a specific period. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Percent
description: Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  Values that have had the effect of price changes removed, expressed as time series in constant prices (fixed base) or chain-linked volume terms, or as non-time series in previous year's prices A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Gross domestic product (GDP), Price deflator, Index
description: Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  An economic indicator used to adjust nominal economic data series for changes in relevant price levels.  Price deflators can be explicit, such as producer or consumer price indices, or implicit, such as the GDP deflator derived by dividing nominal GDP by GDP in volume terms. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

name: Gross domestic product (GDP), Constant prices, Percent change
description: Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. Values that have had the effect of price changes removed, expressed as time series in constant prices (fixed base) or chain-linked volume terms, or as non-time series in previous year's prices This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. The import price of a commodity. Price or cost in US cents per pound.

name: Financial account balance (assets less liabilities), US dollar
description: The financial account balance reflects the difference in transactions in financial assets and liabilities in the accounting period. In the external accounts, only transactions between residents and non-residents are included.

name: Uranium, Unit prices, US dollars per pound
description: Uranium, NUEXCO, Restricted Price, Nuexco exchange spot, US$ per pound. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. The unitary price of an item or commodity. Price or cost in US dollars per pound.

name: Current account balance (credit less debit), Percent of GDP
description: The current account balance is the balance of current transactions (transactions in goods and services, earned income and transfer income) between residents and non-residents. The term current account balance is used in the external accounts and is expressed from the perspective of resident units. The term current external balance is used in the national accounts and is expressed from the perspective of the non-resident units, and therefore with the opposite sign.  Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Structural balance, General government, Domestic currency
description: The government's budget balance adjusted for the economic cycle, representing the underlying fiscal position. Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

name: Portfolio investment, Net (assets minus liabilities), US dollar
description: Portfolio investment reflects cross-border transactions and positions involving debt or equity securities, other than those included in direct investment or reserve assets.  The net value obtained by subtracting total liabilities from total assets.

name: Expenditure, General government, Percent of GDP
description: Expenditure refers to the total outflow of resources, including payments, purchases, and transfers, made by a government entity during a specific period to fulfill its various functions and obligations. It encompasses spending on goods and services, wages and salaries, social benefits, debt servicing, infrastructure investments, and other government programs and activities. Expenditure represents the utilization of government funds to provide public services, maintain infrastructure, implement policies, and meet financial obligations. Monitoring expenditure patterns and allocations provides insight into government priorities, policy objectives, and fiscal sustainability.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Gross debt, General government, Domestic currency
description: Gross debt is the sum of all liabilities that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

name: Net debt, General government, Domestic currency
description: Net debt is the sum of all liabilities less financial assets that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

name: Gross domestic product (GDP), Current prices, Fiscal year, Domestic currency
description: Gross domestic product reflects the total income earned through the production of goods and services in an economic territory during an accounting period. It can be measured in three different ways: using either the expenditure approach, the income approach, or the production approach.  Values expressed without any adjustment for price changes A 12-month period that a company or government uses for accounting purposes. The fiscal year may or may not align with the calendar year. For example, a company's fiscal year could start on July 1st and end on June 30th of the following year. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. name: External debt, Percent of exports of goods and services
description: Gross external debt reflects liabilities that require payment(s) of interest and/or principal by the debtor at some point(s) in the future and that are owed to non-residents by residents of an economy. Base concept expressed as a ratio to Exports of Goods and Services (BXGS). A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Direct investment, Net (assets minus liabilities), US dollar
description: Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  The net value obtained by subtracting total liabilities from total assets.

name: Exports of goods and services, Volume, Free on board (FOB), Percent change
description: Exports of goods and services reflect the export of goods reflect changes in the economic ownership of goods from residents of the compiling economy to non-residents, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. Exports of services provided by residents to non-residents. The quantity of goods or services produced or traded, often measured in terms of physical units or monetary value. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

Values that have had the effect of price changes removed, expressed as time series in constant prices (fixed base) or chain-linked volume terms, or as non-time series in previous year's prices Average income or economic output per person adjusted for cost-of-living differences between countries, expressed in international dollars. ICP benchmark 2021

name: Exports of manufactures, Price deflator, Free on board (FOB), Index
description: The total value of manufactured goods sold by a country to foreign buyers. An economic indicator used to adjust nominal economic data series for changes in relevant price levels.  Price deflators can be explicit, such as producer or consumer price indices, or implicit, such as the GDP deflator derived by dividing nominal GDP by GDP in volume terms. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

name: Imports of goods and services, Volume, Cost insurance freight (CIF), Percent change
description: Imports of goods and services reflect the change in the economic ownership of goods from non-residents to residents of the compiling economy, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. Imports of services reflect services provided by non-residents to residents The quantity of goods or services produced or traded, often measured in terms of physical units or monetary value. The c.i.f. price (i.e. cost, insurance and freight price) is the price of a good delivered at the frontier of the importing country, including any insurance and freight charges incurred to that point, or the price of a service delivered to a resident, before the payment of any import duties or other taxes on imports or trade and transport margins within the country.  This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Net lending (+) / net borrowing (-), General government, Domestic currency
description: Net lending is defined as the difference between changes in net worth due to saving and capital transfers and net acquisitions of non-financial assets (acquisitions less disposals of non-financial assets, less depreciation). If the amount is negative, it represents net borrowing. In the external accounts, it represents the sum of the balances on the current and capital accounts. This is conceptually  equal to the net balance of the financial account. If the balance is positive, it is called net lending, implying that in net terms, the economy supplies funds to the rest of the world. If the balance is negative, it is called net borrowing, implying that in net terms, the economy receives funds from the rest of the world.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

name: All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), Period average
description: All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. This refers to the arithmetic mean (average) value of a data series calculated over a specified period, such as a month, quarter, or year. It provides a representative value for the entire period, smoothing out any short-term fluctuations. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to preserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published. A commodity price index is a measurement tool that tracks the average price changes of a basket of commodities over time. These commodities can include various raw materials or primary agricultural products A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

name: All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), End-of-period (EoP)
description: All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. Refers to the end of any specific period, such as a quarter, month, or week. It marks the point at which economic or financial data or indexes are aggregated and/or analyzed. A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

name: Primary net lending (+) / net borrowing (-), General government, Domestic currency
description: Primary net lending/borrowing refers to the difference between a government's total revenue (excluding borrowing) and its total expenditures (excluding debt repayments and interest payments). It represents the government's fiscal position, indicating whether it is running a surplus (positive value) or a deficit (negative value) before considering the impact of debt servicing costs.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.�

name: Exports of goods, Volume, Free on board (FOB), Percent change
description: Exports of goods reflects the change in the economic ownership of goods from residents of the compiling economy to non-residents, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. The quantity of goods or services produced or traded, often measured in terms of physical units or monetary value. The f.o.b. price (free on board price) of exports and imports of goods is the market value of the goods at the point of uniform valuation, (the customs frontier of the economy from which they are exported).  It is equal to the c.i.f. price less the costs of transportation and insurance charges, between the customs frontier of the exporting (importing) country and that of the importing (exporting) country. This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Imports of goods, Volume, Cost insurance freight (CIF), Percent change
description: Imports of goods reflects the change in the economic ownership of goods from non-residents to residents of the compiling economy, irrespective of physical movement of goods across national borders. The quantity of goods or services produced or traded, often measured in terms of physical units or monetary value. The c.i.f. price (i.e. cost, insurance and freight price) is the price of a good delivered at the frontier of the importing country, including any insurance and freight charges incurred to that point, or the price of a service delivered to a resident, before the payment of any import duties or other taxes on imports or trade and transport margins within the country.  This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1 A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), Period average, percent change
description: All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. This calculates the change relative to the average value over the entire period, not just the starting point. This is often used when the data fluctuates significantly within the period, and the average provides a more representative value for comparison. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: All Items, Consumer price index (CPI), End-of-period (EoP), percent change
description: All items in the context of the consumer price index indicates that the index includes prices for all items included in the consumer price index basket.  This includes prices related to food, beverages, clothing, housing, health, transport, communications, recreation, education, restaurants and hotels and other miscellanoues goods and services. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is an index of the prices of consumption goods and services, as compared to a certain reference period. This focuses on the change between the value at the beginning of a period and the value at the end of that period. The period could be a day, month, quarter, year, etc. This is often used to track changes in financial or economic indicators over specific periods. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Gross capital formation, Percent of GDP
description: Acquisitions less disposals of produced assets for purposes of fixed capital formation, inventories or valuables. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Vegetable oil, Commodity price index
description: Vegetable Oil Index, 2016 = 100, includes Soybean, Soybean Meal, Soybean Oil, Coconut Oil, Palm Oil, Sunflower Oil and Olive Oil Price Indices. This indicator appears in other datasets published by the IMF. While every effort is made to ensure that estimates for the same indicator are consistent across different datasets, differences can occur due to differences in compilation methodology, reference year, splicing series to preserve time-series continuity, and when the data were collected, processed, and published. A commodity price index is a measurement tool that tracks the average price changes of a basket of commodities over time. These commodities can include various raw materials or primary agricultural products A statistical measure that expresses the relative change in a variable over time.

name: Cyclically adjusted primary balance, General government, Percent of potential GDP
description: The cyclically adjusted primary balance is similar to the cyclically adjusted balance but focuses specifically on the primary balance, which excludes interest payments on government debt. It adjusts the primary balance for the effects of the economic cycle to provide a measure of the structural fiscal position of the government, independent of cyclical fluctuations. Like the cyclically adjusted balance, a positive cyclically adjusted primary balance indicates a structural surplus, while a negative cyclically adjusted primary balance indicates a structural deficit.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percentage of potential GDP. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Cyclically adjusted balance, General government, Percent of potential GDP
description: The cyclically adjusted balance is a measure of a government's budget balance that takes into account the effects of the economic cycle. It adjusts the actual budget balance for the impact of cyclical fluctuations in economic activity, such as changes in output, employment, and tax revenues, to provide a clearer picture of the underlying fiscal position. This adjustment helps policymakers assess the structural or underlying fiscal position of the government, independent of temporary fluctuations caused by the economic cycle. A positive cyclically adjusted balance indicates a structural surplus, while a negative cyclically adjusted balance indicates a structural deficit.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percentage of potential GDP. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Net lending (+) / net borrowing (-), General government, Percent of GDP
description: Net lending is defined as the difference between changes in net worth due to saving and capital transfers and net acquisitions of non-financial assets (acquisitions less disposals of non-financial assets, less depreciation). If the amount is negative, it represents net borrowing. In the external accounts, it represents the sum of the balances on the current and capital accounts. This is conceptually  equal to the net balance of the financial account. If the balance is positive, it is called net lending, implying that in net terms, the economy supplies funds to the rest of the world. If the balance is negative, it is called net borrowing, implying that in net terms, the economy receives funds from the rest of the world.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Primary net lending (+) / net borrowing (-), General government, Percent of GDP
description: Primary net lending/borrowing refers to the difference between a government's total revenue (excluding borrowing) and its total expenditures (excluding debt repayments and interest payments). It represents the government's fiscal position, indicating whether it is running a surplus (positive value) or a deficit (negative value) before considering the impact of debt servicing costs.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Expenditure, General government, Percent of GDP
description: Expenditure refers to the total outflow of resources, including payments, purchases, and transfers, made by a government entity during a specific period to fulfill its various functions and obligations. It encompasses spending on goods and services, wages and salaries, social benefits, debt servicing, infrastructure investments, and other government programs and activities. Expenditure represents the utilization of government funds to provide public services, maintain infrastructure, implement policies, and meet financial obligations. Monitoring expenditure patterns and allocations provides insight into government priorities, policy objectives, and fiscal sustainability.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Gross debt, General government, Percent of GDP
description: Gross debt is the sum of all liabilities that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Revenue, General government, Percent of GDP
description: Revenue refers to the total inflow of resources, typically in the form of taxes, fees, charges, grants, and other income, received by a government entity during a specific period. It represents the funds generated by the government through its various activities and sources, including taxation, sales of goods or services, investment income, and transfers from other entities.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Net debt, General government, Percent of GDP
description: Net debt is the sum of all liabilities less financial assets that are debt instruments.  Debt instruments are financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future. Debt instruments consist of SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, pension and related entitlements, provision for calls under standardized guarantees, and other accounts receivable/payable.  Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country. A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Capital transfers, Financial corporations, nonfinancial corporations, households, and NPISHs
description: Transfers that involve the transfer of ownership of fixed assets, the forgiveness of liabilities, or the provision of funds linked to the acquisition or disposal of fixed assets. All institutional sectors except the rest of the world.

name: Secondary income, Financial corporations, nonfinancial corporations, households, and NPISHs
description: Secondary incomes are incomes arising from the distribution of income between institutional units via current transfers. In the context of the external accounts, this account records current transfers between residents and non-residents. All institutional sectors except the rest of the world.

name: Other investment, Insurance, pension and standardized guarantee schemes
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Reserves, entitlements, and provisions representing liabilities of the insurer, pension fund, or issuer of standardized guarantees, and a corresponding asset of the policyholders or beneficiaries.

name: Other investment, Insurance, pension and standardized guarantee schemes, Central bank
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Reserves, entitlements, and provisions representing liabilities of the insurer, pension fund, or issuer of standardized guarantees, and a corresponding asset of the policyholders or beneficiaries. The monetary authority of a country responsible for issuing currency and regulating the banking system.

name: Goods and services
description: Goods are physical, produced objects, over which ownership rights can be established and whose ownership can be transferred from one institutional unit to another by engaging in transactions on markets. Services result from a production activity that changes the conditions of the consuming units, or facilitates the exchange of products or financial assets. Services are not generally separate items over which ownership rights can be established and cannot generally be separated from their production.

name: Secondary income
description: Secondary incomes are incomes arising from the distribution of income between institutional units via current transfers. In the context of the external accounts, this account records current transfers between residents and non-residents.

name: Net lending (+) / net borrowing (-)
description: Net lending is the difference between changes in net worth due to saving and capital transfers and net acquisitions of non-financial assets (acquisitions less disposals of non-financial assets, less depreciation). If the amount is negative, it represents net borrowing. In the external accounts, it represents the sum of the balances on the current and capital accounts. This is conceptually  equal to the net balance of the financial account. If the balance is positive, it is called net lending, implying that in net terms, the economy supplies funds to the rest of the world. If the balance is negative, it is called net borrowing, implying that in net terms, the economy receives funds from the rest of the world.

name: Current account balance (credit less debit)
description: The current account balance is the balance of current transactions (transactions in goods and services, earned income and transfer income) between residents and non-residents. The term current account balance is used in the external accounts and is expressed from the perspective of resident units. The term current external balance is used in the national accounts and is expressed from the perspective of the non-resident units, and therefore with the opposite sign.

name: Capital account balance (credit less debit)

name: Special Drawing Rights (SDRs): allocations, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: SDR allocations are reserve assets created by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and allocated to its member countries to supplement existing reserve assets. Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) are international reserve assets that the IMF allocates to its members as a form of supplementary liquidity. These allocations are based on each member country's IMF quota and are intended to provide additional liquidity and support to the global financial system. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Other investment, Special Drawing Rights (SDRs): allocations, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  SDR allocations are reserve assets created by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and allocated to its member countries to supplement existing reserve assets. Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) are international reserve assets that the IMF allocates to its members as a form of supplementary liquidity. These allocations are based on each member country's IMF quota and are intended to provide additional liquidity and support to the global financial system. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Reserve assets created by the International Monetary Fund and allocated to its members to supplement existing reserve assets. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Direct investment, Investment fund shares/units, Money market funds
description: Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  Shares or units in a fund that pools investor money to purchase securities. Investment funds that invest in short-term debt instruments.

name: Direct investment
description: Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.

name: Other investment, Loans, credit, and loans with the IMF (other than reserves), Central bank, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Financial instruments including loans, credit, and loans with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), excluding those held as reserves. The monetary authority of a country responsible for issuing currency and regulating the banking system. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Direct investment between fellow enterprises, Equity and investment fund shares
description: Investment between enterprises that are both controlled by the same parent entity. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Other investment
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.

name: Other short-term foreign currency liabilities to nonresidents: reserve-related liabilities (RRL) to nonresidents
description: Short-term foreign currency liabilities to nonresidents that are classified as reserve-related liabilities.

name: Portfolio investment
description: Portfolio investment reflects cross-border transactions and positions involving debt or equity securities, other than those included in direct investment or reserve assets.

name: Direct investor in direct invesment enterprises, Equity and investment fund shares
description: An investor that makes direct investment in enterprises, having control or significant influence. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Reserve Assets included in SDR basket
description: Reserve Assets included in SDR basket

name: Direct investment, Investment fund shares/units
description: Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  Shares or units in a fund that pools investor money to purchase securities.

name: Direct investment enterprises in direct investor, Equity and investment fund shares
description: Enterprises in which direct investment is made by the investor. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Other investment, Debt instruments, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Financial instruments that require the payment of principal and/or interest at some point(s) in the future, including SDRs, currency and deposits, debt securities, loans, insurance technical reserves, and other accounts receivable/payable. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Other investment, Loans, credit, and loans with the IMF (other than reserves), General government, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Financial instruments including loans, credit, and loans with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), excluding those held as reserves. Central, state, and local governments, including their agencies and departments. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Direct investment between fellow enterprises if ultimate controlling parent is unknown, Equity and investment fund shares
description: Investment between enterprises controlled by the same parent entity, where the status of the parent entity's residency is unknown. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Direct investment between fellow enterprises if ultimate controlling parent is resident, Equity and investment fund shares
description: Investment between enterprises controlled by the same parent entity, where the parent entity is a resident of the country. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Direct investment between fellow enterprises if ultimate controlling parent is nonresident, Equity and investment fund shares
description: Investment between enterprises controlled by the same parent entity, where the parent entity is not a resident of the country. Ownership interest in companies (equity) and shares in investment funds.

name: Credit and loans from the IMF: reserve-related liabilities (RRL) to nonresidents
description: Reserve-related liabilities owed to nonresidents arising from credit and loans provided by the IMF.

name: Other investment, Other debt instruments, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Debt instruments not classified under specific categories like bonds or loans. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Other investment, Short-term
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Original contract stipulates that payment is due in one year or less or payable on demand (referred to as short-term maturity).

name: Other investment, Long-term
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Original contract stipulates that payment is due in more than one year, or has no stated maturity (referred to as long-term maturity)

name: Acquisitions (net): nonproduced assets
description: The purchases of nonproduced assets, such as land and natural resources, during the accounting period.

name: Direct investment, Primary income
description: Direct Investment represents cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the voting power is evidence of a direct investment relationship.  Primary incomes are incomes earned by institutional units as a consequence of their involvement in processes of production or ownership of assets that may be needed for purposes of production.

name: Financial account balance (assets less liabilities)
description: The financial account balance reflects the difference in transactions in financial assets and liabilities in the accounting period. In the external accounts, only transactions between residents and non-residents are included.

name: Foreign currency derivatives by sector notional value of contracts with nonresidents total
description: The aggregate notional value of all foreign currency derivative contracts with nonresidents, categorized by sector.

name: Debt claims on nonresidents, inter-company lending
description: Claims for debt owed by nonresidents arising from inter-company lending.

name: Foreign currency derivatives by sector notional value of contracts with nonresidents, Deposit taking corporations, except the Central Bank

name: Debt liabilities to nonresidents: inter-company lending
description: Liabilities owed to nonresidents arising from inter-company lending.

name: Foreign currency derivatives by sector notional value of contracts with nonresidents, Central bank
description: The total notional value of foreign currency derivative contracts with nonresidents, categorized by sector. The monetary authority of a country responsible for issuing currency and regulating the banking system.

description: The total notional value of foreign currency derivative contracts with nonresidents, categorized by sector. Miscellaneous or residual sectors not classified elsewhere.

name: Financial derivatives (other than reserves) and employee stock options
description: Negotiable financial instruments and employee stock options that are linked to other specific financial instruments, indicators, or commodities. Financial derivatives excluding those held as reserves and employee stock options.

description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets. name: Net International Investment Position, Adjusted using IMF accounting records

description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). name: Reserve assets, Debt securities, Short-term
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Tradable financial instruments representing a debt, such as bonds and notes. name: Transport, Passenger, Of which: Payable by Border, Seasonal, and Other S-T Workers
description: Transport, Passenger, Of which: Payable by Border, Seasonal, and Other S-T Workers

name: Travel services, Both Business and Personal Travel, Other Services
description: Travel services, Both Business and Personal Travel, Other Services.

name: Other investment, Special Drawing Rights (SDRs)
description: Other investment represents a residual investment category that includes positions and transactions other than those included in direct investment, portfolio investment, financial derivatives and employee stock options, and reserve assets.  Reserve assets created by the International Monetary Fund and allocated to its members to supplement existing reserve assets.

name: Reserve assets, Special Drawing Rights (SDRs)
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Reserve assets created by the International Monetary Fund and allocated to its members to supplement existing reserve assets.

name: Reserve assets, Monetary gold: gold bullion
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Gold in the form of bars or ingots held as a reserve asset.

name: Reserve assets, Monetary gold: of which gold under swap for cash collateral
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Portion of monetary gold that is held under swap agreements for cash collateral.

name: Reserve assets, Unallocated gold accounts
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Unallocated gold accounts.

name: Reserve assets, Financial derivatives
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Negotiable financial instruments linked to another specific financial instrument, indicator, or commodity, through which specific risks (e.g., interest rate risk, foreign exchange risk, equity and commodity price risk, credit risk) can be traded in their own right in financial markets. Financial instruments whose value is derived from the performance of underlying assets, indexes, or interest rates.

name: Reserve assets, Currency and deposits
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Monetary assets held in the form of currency or in deposit accounts with financial institutions.

name: Reserve assets, Debt securities
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Tradable financial instruments representing a debt, such as bonds and notes.

name: Investment income on other investment income
description: Investment income

description: Reserves and Related items.

name: Financial account balance, excluding reserves and related items
description: Financial account balance, excluding reserves and related items.

description: The financial account balance reflects the difference in transactions in financial assets and liabilities in the accounting period. In the external accounts, only transactions between residents and non-residents are included. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Reserve assets, Currency and deposits, Claims on monetary authorities
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Monetary assets held in the form of currency or in deposit accounts with financial institutions, claims on monetary authorities.

name: Reserve assets, Currency and deposits, Claims on other entities
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Monetary assets held in the form of currency or in deposit accounts with financial institutions, claims on other entities.

name: Reserve assets, Reserve position in the IMF
description: External assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, for intervention in exchange markets to affect the currency exchange rate, and for other related purposes (such as maintaining confidence in the currency and the economy, and serving as a basis for foreign borrowing). Reserve assets must be denominated and settled in foreign currency.  Reserve position in the IMF is the sum of a member’s reserve tranche position and any indebtedness of the IMF in the General Resources Account (GRA) that is readily available to the member to meet balance of payments financing needs.

name: Total liabilities, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: The total value of all financial obligations owed by an entity to other entities. These obligations represent claims held by others against the entity and may include loans, debt securities, accounts payable, and other forms of debt. This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Total assets, Adjusted using IMF accounting records
description: Total assets This indicator has been adjusted using IMF accounting records received from the IMF Finance Department.

name: Debt liabilities to nonresidents
description: Liabilities owed to nonresidents in the form of debt.

name: Debt liabilities to nonresidents, Short-term
description: Liabilities owed to nonresidents in the form of debt. Original contract stipulates that payment is due in one year or less or payable on demand (referred to as short-term maturity).

name: Debt liabilities to nonresidents, Other Sectors (BPM6), Short-term
description: Liabilities owed to nonresidents in the form of debt. Sectors excluding deposit-taking corporations and general government. Original contract stipulates that payment is due in one year or less or payable on demand (referred to as short-term maturity).

description: Claims for debt owed by nonresidents. Original contract stipulates that payment is due in one year or less or payable on demand (referred to as short-term maturity).

description: Net open position in foreign exchange to capital The sum of the net position of on-balance sheet foreign currency debt instruments, net positions in financial derivatives, on-balance sheet holdings of foreign currency equity assets, and net position in foreign currency off-balance sheet items.

name: Gross asset position in financial derivatives to capital, Gross asset position in financial derivatives, US dollar
description: Gross asset position in financial derivatives to capital. description: Geographic distribution of loans: advanced economies. Additional FSIs A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

The outstanding amount of provisions made against the value of individual non-performing loans, collectively assessed groups of loans, and non-performing loans to other Deposit takers, in accordance with the national regulatory framework. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Residential real estate prices (percentage change/last 12 months), (Additional FSI), Percent
description: Residential real estate prices (percentage change/last 12 months). Additional FSIs A ratio expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: Liquid assets to estimated pension payments in the next year, Estimated pension payments in the next 12 months, Euro
description: Liquid assets to estimated pension payments in the next year. The sum of the actuarially expected payments to beneficiaries by pension funds during the next year.

name: Liquid assets to total assets, Total assets, Euro
description: Liquid assets to total assets. The sum of nonfinancial and financial assets, representing the total resources owned by the institutional unit.

name: Loans to Advanced Economies, Loans to Advanced Economies, Euro
description: Loans to advanced economies. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Advanced Economies.

name: Credit growth to private sector, Credit to the private sector, Domestic currency
description: Credit growth to private sector. Gross loans extended to the private nonfinancial sector, plus debt securities issued by private nonfinancial corporations and held by Deposit takers. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Return on equity (Life insurance only), Average capital and reserves, Domestic currency
description: Return on equity (Life insurance only). The average value of capital and reserves from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Return on assets, Net income before taxes, Domestic currency
description: The quotient of net income before taxes and total (financial and nonfinancial) assets, expressed as a percentage. The estimated total net income before tax that the institutional unit would earn over a year, calculated based on the amount earned and accumulated from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Liquid assets to total assets, Liquid assets, Domestic currency
description: Liquid assets to total assets. Assets that are readily available to meet cash demands, including currency, deposits, and tradable securities that can be converted into cash with insignificant risk of change in value under normal business conditions. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Loans to Sub-Saharan Africa, Loans to Sub-Saharan Africa, US dollar
description: Loans to sub-saharan africa. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Return on equity, Equity, Domestic currency
description: The quotient of net income after taxes and total capital and reserves, expressed as a percentage. The difference between total assets and total liabilities in the balance sheet, and it represents the equity interest of the owners in an entity and is the amount available to absorb unidentified losses. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Nonperforming loans to total gross loans, Nonperforming loans, Euro
description: Nonperforming loans to total gross loans. Loans for which (1) payments of interest or principal are past due by 90 days or more; or (2) interest payments equal to 90 days or more have been capitalized, refinanced, or rolled over; or (3) evidence exists to reclassify them as nonperforming even in the absence of a 90-day past due payment, such as when the debtor files for bankruptcy.

name: Return on equity, Net income after taxes, Domestic currency
description: The quotient of net income after taxes and total capital and reserves, expressed as a percentage. The remainder of net income after deducting income tax.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Return on assets (Life insurance only), Net income before taxes, Domestic currency
description: Return on assets (Life insurance only). The estimated total net income before tax that the institutional unit would earn over a year, calculated based on the amount earned and accumulated from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Return on equity (Nonlife insurance only), Annualized net income after taxes, Domestic currency
description: Return on equity (Nonlife insurance only). The estimated total net income after taxes that the institutional unit would earn over a year, calculated based on the amount earned and accumulated from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Earnings to interest and principal expenses, Earnings before interest and tax, US dollar
description: Earnings to interest and principal expenses. The net operating income plus interest income plus other income (net) less interest income receivable from other nonfinancial corporations.

name: Trading income to total income, Gross income, Euro
description: Trading income to total income. The sum of net income from insurance activity and other operating income.

name: Tier 1 capital to assets, Total assets, US dollar
description: The ratio of Tier 1 capital to total balance sheet assets or the Basel III exposure measure, expressed as a percentage. The sum of nonfinancial and financial assets, representing the total resources owned by the institutional unit.

name: Liquid assets to short term liabilities, Liquid assets, US dollar
description: Liquid assets to short term liabilities Assets that are readily available to meet cash demands, including currency, deposits, and tradable securities that can be converted into cash with insignificant risk of change in value under normal business conditions.

name: Liquid assets to short term liabilities, Short term , US dollar
description: Liquid assets to short term liabilities Liabilities that are due on demand or within three months or less.

name: Return on equity (Life insurance only), Annualized net income after taxes, Domestic currency
description: Return on equity (Life insurance only). The estimated total net income after taxes that the institutional unit would earn over a year, calculated based on the amount earned and accumulated from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Interest margin to gross income, Interest margin, Euro
description: Interest margin to gross income. The difference between interest income and interest expense.

name: Loans to Sub-Saharan Africa, Loans to Sub-Saharan Africa, Euro
description: Loans to sub-saharan africa. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Liquid assets to short term liabilities, Short term , Euro
description: Liquid assets to short term liabilities Liabilities that are due on demand or within three months or less.

name: Liquid assets to short term liabilities, Liquid assets, Euro
description: Liquid assets to short term liabilities Assets that are readily available to meet cash demands, including currency, deposits, and tradable securities that can be converted into cash with insignificant risk of change in value under normal business conditions.

name: Provisions to nonperforming loans, Nonperforming loans, US dollar
description: Provisions to nonperforming loans. Loans for which (1) payments of interest or principal are past due by 90 days or more; or (2) interest payments equal to 90 days or more have been capitalized, refinanced, or rolled over; or (3) evidence exists to reclassify them as nonperforming even in the absence of a 90-day past due payment, such as when the debtor files for bankruptcy.

name: Loans to Emerging and Developing Europe, Loans to Emerging and Developing Europe, Domestic currency
description: Loans to emerging and developing europe. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Emerging and Developing Europe. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Liquidity coverage ratio, High quality liquid assets, Domestic currency
description: Liquidity coverage ratio. Assets held by deposit takers to meet short-term liquidity needs during periods of financial stress. These assets are characterized by their low risk, high credit quality, and ability to be quickly converted into cash with minimal loss in value, and the scope of these assets is defined by the national regulatory framework based on Basel III framework. Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Loan concentration by economic activity, Total gross loans to nonfinancial corporations, Domestic currency
description: Loan concentration by economic activity. Loans granted to non-financial corporations.  Currency issued by the country of origin, used internally. Used to specify what Unit of Measure the country used to provide data to the IMF.

name: Earnings to interest and principal expenses, Debt-service payments (interest and principal), US dollar
description: Earnings to interest and principal expenses. The interest and principal payable on outstanding debt liabilities during the reporting period.

name: Earnings to interest and principal expenses, Earnings before interest and tax, Euro
description: Earnings to interest and principal expenses. The net operating income plus interest income plus other income (net) less interest income receivable from other nonfinancial corporations.

name: Provisions to nonperforming loans, Specific provisions, US dollar
description: Provisions to nonperforming loans. The outstanding amount of provisions made against the value of individual non-performing loans, collectively assessed groups of loans, and non-performing loans to other Deposit takers, in accordance with the national regulatory framework.

name: Large exposures to capital, Tier 1 capital, US dollar
description: Large exposures to capital. Comprises paid-up shares and common stock, and disclosed reserves that are available to meet claims against the deposit taker, with deductions such as goodwill. It is a supervisory concept defined by National regulation and based on Basel I, II, or III framework.

name: Tier 1 capital to assets, Total assets, Euro
description: The ratio of Tier 1 capital to total balance sheet assets or the Basel III exposure measure, expressed as a percentage. The sum of nonfinancial and financial assets, representing the total resources owned by the institutional unit.

description: Loans to emerging and developing asia. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Emerging and Developing Asia.

description: Return on equity (Nonlife insurance only). The average value of capital and reserves from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.

name: Return on assets (Life insurance only), Average total assets, US dollar
description: Return on assets (Life insurance only). The average value of total assets from the start of the calendar year to the end of the current reporting period.

name: Trading income to total income, Trading income, US dollar
description: Trading income to total income. Realized and unrealized gains and losses during the period on all financial instruments (assets and liabilities) that are held at Fair value through profit and loss on the balance sheet.

description: Loans to emerging and developing europe. Loans extended to non-residents domiciled in Emerging and Developing Europe.
